they're enforcing support supports starting now. 

the article is laughable. ban a support singed and then post a topic stating that the goal is to make support role more attractive to more players without taking away from what makes it appealing to existing support players. i guess that means banning the players who actually want to play support even if it's in a nontraditional sense.
> 
> > At present support is a position that significantly fewer players want to play than other roles. That’s unfortunate because it results in:
> > 
> >     Long matchmaking queues (not enough support players to go around).
> >     Players having to play a role they’d prefer not to (getting autofilled to support to partially address the above problem).
> >     Players having to play a role more often than they’d prefer (if they want to queue as support secondary or fill).
> > 
> > We’d therefore like to make support attractive to more players, without taking away what makes it appealing to existing support players. That’s something we’re planning to put quite a bit of work into in 2017 after we’ve got the pre-season changes generally polished and balanced.

Watch the video, he is objectively NOT playing 'support' singed. It is purely a double jungle strategy. Comparing this to bard is just wrong, does Bard not even enter bot lane until level 9?

If you are complaining that the current system does not support alternate strategies, like double jungle, than that is something you can do. But he was queueing up as support, then refusing to fulfill what that role means within League regardless of his teams objections.

I am willing to bet if he was actually bot lane there would be no issues, but he is playing in a way that is simply not supported in the current system unless you are also queuing up with others who are ok with your strategies.

im sorry what? do you even bother to pay attention to any of his builds or his actual games? the video shows his name. clearly states it in the video. that singed players name when i searched it up shows a singed player with 2m points that is gold in solo/duo and silver in flex. it shows that the person the video is referring to DOES build income items DOES build support items and DOES have assists. in fact he has more assists than anyone on his team. he might not ward, but he does support. 

HE LITERALLY SUPPORTS BETTER THAN MANY OF THE PEOPLE WHO ACTUALLY BUYS SIGHT STONE.

I did look up his games, he spends so little time in lane that many sites often list him as a jungler, even when there is the obvious REAL person who was given the jungle role in game (they are a traditional jungle champion w/ smite and jungle items and that team lacks a traditional support champion with support items). These sites seem to know what a lot of people are overlooking, that what this Singed is doing is called JUNGLING.

Your argument is basically 'he has assists, therefore he is a support' which is confirmed later when you say he "supports better" which of course you have no idea or metric of outside of assists.

This is just wrong, if I play Zac jungle and build full initiator/tank I will naturally get a lot of assists and relatively few kills. Does that make me a support? If I play support Annie or Brand and end up with less assists than the enemy Janna does that make me a 'bad' support?

Supporting is a very specific role in League. It does not just mean 'support the team in their chances of victory' because that literally applies to every possible strategy. Queueing up as a support than NOT doing that role is what people are pissed about, and in my opinion rightfully so.

Of course this comment is going to come under fire from people proposing that this 'enforces the meta' and 'stifles creativity' and truth be told, it does. But that is the sacrifice for creating 5v5 competitive matches made of 10 people who know nothing about each other. In an ideal world each game would start with some strategizing and off the wall ideas would be experimented with in that conversation, any person who has actually played ranked knows that this does not happen. People want a framework for what they are doing, the success of the new queue where you start off by picking a role shows this off well, that queue obviously 'enforced the meta' but the player base was overwhelmingly supportive of it.

Playing in a way that is supported by none of the traditional roles is a problem in a pick up group type queue, especially if you continue despite what everyone else wants. If you want to break the mold that is fine, just find people that want to do it with you.

------------------------------------
Enjoy Yourself, but not at Anyone Else's Expense

"Short is the joy that guilty pleasure brings." -Euripides

Making games is our business, so it should come as no surprise that we want you to have a lot of fun. We want you to get excited, to have tension-filled moments, and to celebrate your success. This doesn't mean that we're okay with you ruining anybody else's day.

Remember, taking a jab at your friend in the middle of the game is a lot different than making a glib remark at a complete stranger. Someone who is unfamiliar with what you consider playful may take your comment as an attack and react unfavorably. If two players on a team start fighting, good communication and teamwork become nearly impossible. Once communication breaks down, the likelihood of victory is drastically diminished. It isn't uncommon for simple, good natured teasing to spiral out of control into a loss, so do yourself a favor and don't run the risk of sabotaging your own success.

----------------------------------

this is saying that players should not harass each other and call each other names. it says absolutely nothing about choosing the champion your team wants you to choose. in fact. let me post the first rule for you.

-------------------------------------


Support Your Team

"[Teamwork] is the fuel that allows common people to attain uncommon results." -Andrew Carnegie

While we all carry a diverse set of individual ambitions and expectations into a game of League of Legends, once we hit the Field we're a part of a team. For better or worse, our fates are intertwined with that of our teammates. Once the game gets into full swing, you have to make a choice between being a positive force for your team, or contributing to your own demise.

Being a good team player begins at champion select. Be open minded when considering the needs of your team. If you're the last one to pick, try to fill a niche in your team that hasn't already been filled. If everyone's picked and something stands out as a deficiency in your team composition, try asking for another player to fill the gap, or change roles to embrace that responsibility yourself. Remember, that by taking on a role you don't normally play, you'll learn more about unfamiliar champions and increase your own skill level.

Once you get in game, try to keep an open line of communication. Warn your teammates if someone is missing from your lane, or if something is placing them in immediate danger. If they're not paying attention to chat you can always try pinging the map. Just remember that one ping is enough! Also, remember that you have to be there to contribute, so don't leave the game or go AFK! Encourage players who are having trouble, and congratulate those who are playing well. And most of all, if you're having a bad game don't take it out on your team!

--------------------------
Be Resolute, not Indignant

"It is easier to find men who will volunteer to die, than to find those who are willing to endure pain with patience." -Julius Caesar

Intrinsic to the idea of competition is the notion that, when our pride is on the line, emotions tend to run high. Every person that we encounter is going to carry a different set of circumstances with them into the game, and therefore is going to have a different level of tolerance for frustration. If you end up in a game with an abusive player, don't lower yourself to their level. Instead, politely ask them to calm down.And remember, even if you're having a bad game, quitting or going AFK just ruins the game for the rest of the players. If someone's really starting to bother you, the mute and ignore commands are always there to resolve the situation.

And remember, while nobody likes being insulted, it pays to take a moment to consider the circumstances. Remember that this is a competitive game, and, more often than not, the other player is just venting their frustration. Try not to take it personally. Everyone has a breaking point and everyone rages sometimes. At some point you may find yourself in the other person's shoes.
